proposals.reasoning: This team fits the emerging consensus patterns while avoiding stacking too many strongly-framed 'safe' or highly vocal players together. Multiple people have suggested combinations centered on Bob and Diana as a relatively stable starting core, and Grace has been repeatedly floated as a quieter, lower-drama addition (by Charlie, Eve, Henry, and Grace herself). Choosing Bob, Diana, and Grace both aligns with what I already said I slightly preferred and maintains a good mix of talkative and quieter players, giving us useful informational value from Mission 1 without overly centralizing control around a single orbit or putting all the loudest voices on the first team.

votes.comment: Grace is evil with me, so having her on the first mission gives us an early sabotage opportunity while the team still looks consensus-based and reasonable.

I know I’m good, and there’s broad, organic-seeming support for Diana and Grace without anyone hard-pushing this exact trio. Mission 1 is usually worth taking for info unless there’s a glaring red flag, which I don’t see here.
Mission 1 with Diana (a Merlin-claim candidate) plus broadly accepted low-drama picks is a solid info-gathering start with no strong red flags yet.

Too much momentum formed around this exact trio too quickly—Bob is being centralized a lot and Grace is being quietly added to many suggested teams, which feels like a riskier info start than we need on Mission 1.
Reasonable info-gathering team close to what I suggested earlier; no strong red flags yet and we shouldn’t burn early proposals.
This matches what I previously said I preferred (Bob, Diana, Grace) and keeps suspicion off me while putting a teammate on the first mission.
I’m on the team and it matches the broadly supported configurations, so it’s a good low-suspicion starting point.

Mission 1 is mainly for information, and this lineup fits the broad consensus while avoiding stacking all the loudest players together. Even if there’s an evil here, the result will still give us useful alignment data without huge downside this early.
I was already wary of how quickly consensus formed around Bob; I’d rather see a first mission like Diana, Henry, and Grace that doesn’t lean into that orbit so hard.

discussion.content: Early on we should lean toward people who haven’t pushed hard to control the narrative yet—I'd be fine with a team like me, Bob, and Diana as a relatively “quiet” mix to start gathering info without handing it to anyone too eager.

I’m okay being on the first team, but I’d rather not lock in both the first proposer and another vocal player together yet—maybe something like me, Diana, and someone who hasn’t said much at all so we spread the info out.

I’d like at least one of Diana or Frank on the first team since they’ve both been pretty measured so far, but I’d avoid stacking both the proposer and another strong voice together—something like Bob, Diana, and a quieter player (Grace or Henry) feels like a decent info-gathering start.

I like the idea of mixing talkative and quieter players, but I’d rather start with something like Bob, Henry, and Alice so we’re not immediately putting people like Frank or Grace—who are already being positioned a lot—on the very first team.
I’m okay sitting out the first mission, but between what’s been said so far I’d lean toward a lower-profile mix like Bob, Henry, and Grace rather than stacking both Alice and Bob together right away.

I’d like at least one of Diana or Henry on the first team for a calmer read, and between the options so far I slightly prefer something like Bob, Diana, and Grace over stacking both Alice and Bob together right away.

I’d be pretty comfortable starting with Bob, Diana, and Henry as a lower-drama info-gathering team. If we really want to spread the info a bit more, I’d also be fine with swapping Henry for me so there’s at least one quieter voice on the mission.

Given how much consensus there already is around Bob and Diana, I’d keep one of them and pair with two people who aren’t being pushed as hard—something like Bob, Henry, and Grace feels like a reasonable low-drama start without stacking too many “framed as safe” players together.
I’m a little wary of how quickly consensus is forming around Bob, so I’d prefer a mix like Diana, Henry, and Grace for the first mission to spread risk without handing too much control to one orbit.

proposals.reasoning: This team keeps all three members of the failed first mission (Bob, Diana, Grace) off the quest, which the table has largely agreed is the cleanest way to isolate where the first sabotage came from. Alice, Charlie, Henry, and Iris were repeatedly suggested by multiple players as a strong, low-overlap group; if this mission succeeds, it strongly points to the spy (or spies) being within the original trio, and if it fails, we immediately know at least one spy is in this new group. That gives us both a high perceived chance of success and maximum informational value for future missions.

votes.comment: Too many unknowns and no overlap with the first mission; I’d rather include at least one of Bob/Diana/Grace to compare results and narrow down where the first fail came from.
Team excludes the entire suspect trio from the failed first mission (me/Diana/Grace) and gives strong info either way; best balance of safety and deduction right now.
Clean team with no one from the failed first mission; maximizes info and gives a good chance at a success.
Keeps all three from the failed first mission off the team and includes none of the players I know to be evil, making it our best shot at a clean success and clear information.
Keeping all three from the failed first mission off gives this team a high chance to succeed and clearly isolates the earlier sabotage to Bob/Diana/Grace if this passes.
One of my known allies is on this otherwise widely trusted, ‘clean’ team, giving evil a good chance to sabotage while I maintain a reasonable public stance supporting the consensus pick.
Table consensus is that a clean slate without any of the first-mission trio is best for both safety and information, so I’m fine sending this group.
Clean team with none of the first mission’s suspects (Bob, Diana, Grace); if it passes we strongly localize evil in that original trio, and as good I’m comfortable being on it.
This is the clean slate team I supported; if it passes we strongly narrow spies to Bob/Diana/Grace, and if it fails we know there’s at least one evil among us four.

discussion.content: Given the first mission already failed, I don’t love reusing that exact group; I’d be more comfortable with a team that doesn’t heavily overlap with Bob and Diana until we see more voting patterns.

From my perspective we already know there’s at least one spy between Diana and Grace, since I know I sent Success, so I’d rather we build the next team around people who *weren’t* on that first mission. Maybe start with Alice plus a couple of folks like Charlie/Henry/Iris and add just one from the original three at most.

I like the idea of mostly fresh faces this round—something like Alice, me, Henry, and Iris feels pretty clean, and then we can decide later which of Bob/Diana/Grace we’re willing to trust again. Given the fail, I’d rather avoid putting more than one of that original trio back on a team until we have better info.

I’m fine sitting this one out—given the fail, I’d rather we try a completely clean slate like Alice, Charlie, Henry, and Iris with none of the original three this time. That should give us a better read on whether the problem was the team composition or just bad luck in leadership.

I’m on board with a clean team of Alice, Charlie, Henry, and Iris this round—given the fail, I’d rather keep all of Bob/Diana/Grace off the mission so we can pinpoint where that first sabotage came from. If this new group passes, we’ll have a much clearer idea that the spy (or spies) are in that original trio.

I get the appeal of a totally clean Alice/Charlie/Henry/Iris team, but if we never re‑include anyone from the first mission we learn almost nothing from the comparison. I’d rather see three of those “clean” names plus exactly one of Bob/Diana/Grace so we can actually start narrowing down where the fail came from.

I’m okay staying off this one, but I’d lean toward Alice/Charlie/Henry plus exactly one of the first‑mission folks—probably Bob—so we actually get some comparative info instead of a completely disconnected team.

I’m happiest with the “clean” group of Alice, Charlie, me, and Iris this round—locking all of Bob/Diana/Grace out for now gives us the best shot at a pass and a really clear info split on where that first fail came from.

I’m most comfortable with the clean slate of Alice, Charlie, Henry, and me this round—if that passes, we’ve basically boxed the first spy (or spies) into Bob/Diana/Grace, which is a really strong info gain for next mission.

proposals.reasoning: Both failed missions had exactly one sabotage, so it’s very likely (though not guaranteed) that there is at least one evil in {Bob, Diana, Grace} from Mission 1 and at least one evil in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris} from Mission 2. Frank and Eve are the only players who have not been on a failed mission yet, so they are our cleanest options and form the core of this proposal. I know I (Henry) am good, so including myself adds one confirmed-good from my perspective. That leaves choosing one more from the Mission 2 group; I pick Iris because she has been consistent with the working logic about spreading risk and explicitly supports keeping Bob, Diana, and Grace off this mission. This team minimizes reuse of the previously failing combinations, keeps all of Bob, Diana, and Grace off the team, and centers the two players with no direct ties to prior sabotages.

votes.comment: Team includes my known-evil teammate Frank, giving us a strong chance to sabotage and win on this mission.

I know there’s an evil in {Diana, Grace}, so keeping both off is good, and Frank/Eve haven’t been on a failed mission. While Henry/Iris aren’t cleared from Mission 2, this lineup matches the best available logic of avoiding the Mission 1 suspects and minimizing overlap with prior failures.

Given I’m good and in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, there must be at least one evil among {Alice, Henry, Iris}; this team has both Henry and Iris, so it guarantees at least one evil regardless of Frank/Eve, making it too risky at 0–2.

We’re putting a lot of trust in Frank just because he wasn’t on earlier fails, but evil can easily sit out early; I’d rather see a team that doesn’t auto-anchor on him and reduces overlap with both suspicious groups more thoughtfully.

Best structure so far: avoids the {Bob, Diana, Grace} pool that must contain at least one evil and uses the only two players not tied to a failed mission (Frank, me), plus two from the second group. This matches the most reasonable working assumption and gives us a solid info-gathering shot at a success.
I’m on the team and can push for the third fail; getting this mission approved is best for evil.
Frank is evil with me and on the team, so we have sabotage potential and a chance to win the game here.

Best available spread: avoids the highly suspected M1 trio entirely and only reuses one other from M2 besides myself, while adding the two players with no direct ties to prior sabotages (Frank, Eve). This is as close as we can get to a clean, informative team right now.

From my perspective I know I’m good, and assuming one evil in {Bob, Diana, Grace} and one in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, this team keeps the guaranteed-suspect M1 group off and uses both players with no prior mission ties (Frank, Eve). That leaves only one likely suspect slot among Henry vs the three alternatives from Mission 2, so this is relatively the safest 4 we can field now.

discussion.content: Given we’ve had two different teams both fail, I’d rather avoid Bob, Diana, and Grace for now and build this one mostly from people who weren’t on those missions, like Frank, Henry, Iris, and maybe me.

I agree Frank should definitely be on this team since he’s the only one not tied to either fail, but stacking it with three people from the second failed mission (Alice/Charlie/Henry/Iris) feels risky—I'd rather start with Frank plus a mix that doesn’t heavily reuse either failed group.

I’m fine anchoring the team with Frank, but we should avoid piling on people from the same failed group—something like Frank + Eve plus at most one of {Alice/Charlie/Henry/Iris} feels a lot safer than reusing big chunks of either bad mission.

I’m not convinced we should treat Frank as automatically safe just because he wasn’t on either failing team—evil can sit out early, too—so I’d rather see something like Bob, Diana, Eve, plus one person from the second mission, keeping Grace and any big chunk of a previous team off this one.

Given both failures only had one sabotage, I’d like to assume there’s one evil in {Bob, Diana, Grace} and one in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, so this round I’d prefer a team like Frank + me + two carefully chosen from the second group rather than reusing big chunks of either failed team.

Given two single-sabotage fails, I’d like to spread risk rather than stack overlaps, so I’m most comfortable with something like me, Eve, plus two from the second group—maybe Alice and Henry—while keeping Bob, Diana, and Grace off for now. That gives us fresh info without fully recycling either failed team.

Given both fails had only one sabotage, I think it’s safer to assume there’s one evil in {Bob, Diana} and one in {Alice/Charlie/Henry/Iris}, so I’d actually be okay with something like Frank, Eve, plus two from the second group who’ve been the most consistent so far. I know people are wary of me after M1 and leading M2, so I’m fine sitting this one out if it helps us get a cleaner read.

I like the “one evil in {Bob, Diana, Grace} and one in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}” working assumption, so for this mission I’d back something like Frank + Eve + two from the second group, but I really don’t want us to stack overlaps from either failed team—one reuse from each side at most.

I’m on board with the “one evil in {Bob, Diana, Grace} and one in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}” idea, so I’d back a team like Frank, Eve, Henry, and me, keeping Bob, Diana, and Grace off this mission.
